articles.title: New signs found of giant gas planet in 'Earth's neighbourhood'
articles.summary: The possible planet is just four-and-a-half light years away and may have moons that sustain life.
articles.content:
New signs found of giant gas planet in 'Earth's neighbourhood'

15 hours ago Share Save Georgina Rannard Science correspondent Share Save

NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, R. Hurt (Caltech/IPAC) An artist's drawing of what the new planet might look like. Our Sun is the small dot of light between the two bright stars on the left and right.

Scientists have found strong evidence of a giant gas planet in the nearest star system to our own. At four-and-a-half light years away, the lifeless planet would be a close neighbour to Earth in astronomical terms and could have moons that sustain life. The signs were found in the star system Alpha Centauri by the powerful James Webb Space Telescope. The potential planet was detected last year, but it had disappeared in follow-up observations. Astronomers must now look again to prove it definitely exists.

Scientists are particularly excited about this discovery because of the similarities between the exoplanet's star and our Sun. "Four years is a long way but in galaxy terms, it's very close - it's in our neighbourhood," said Dr Carly Howett, associate professor of space instrumentation at the University of Oxford. "It is around a star that is Sun-like and about the same temperature and brightness. That's really important if we want to think about habitable worlds," she added. The planet would be similar to our solar system's gas giants, Saturn and Jupiter, and would be enveloped in a thick gas cloud. That means it could not support life itself, but it could have moons that are habitable. Jupiter and some other planets in our solar system have icy moons, which researchers believe could support life. Scientists are currently investigating that possibility on missions called Europa Clipper and Juice. But those planets are far away from our life-giving Sun. The potential "new" planet is comparatively close to its star.

Getty Images An illustration of Jupiter's moon Europa where scientists think there could be signs of life in its ocean

articles.title: Rare Type of Black Hole Snacks on Star
articles.summary: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope and NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory teamed up to identify a new possible example of a rare class of black holes, identified by X-ray emission (in purple) in this image released on July 24, 2025. Called NGC 6099 HLX-1, this bright X-ray source seems to reside in a compact star cluster in a giant elliptical galaxy. […]
articles.content:
Science: NASA, ESA, CXC, Yi-Chi Chang (National Tsing Hua University); Image Processing: Joseph DePasquale (STScI)

NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope and NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory teamed up to identify a new possible example of a rare class of black holes, identified by X-ray emission (in purple) in this image released on July 24, 2025. Called NGC 6099 HLX-1, this bright X-ray source seems to reside in a compact star cluster in a giant elliptical galaxy. These rare black holes are called intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) and weigh between a few hundred to a few 100,000 times the mass of our Sun.

Learn more about IMBHs and what studying them can tell us about the universe.

Image credit: Science: NASA, ESA, CXC, Yi-Chi Chang (National Tsing Hua University); Image Processing: Joseph DePasquale (STScI)

articles.personality_title: NASA spots rare intermediate-mass black hole feeding on a star
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Black holes come in different sizes. The smallest are a few times the mass of our Sun, while the largest, called supermassive black holes, weigh millions or billions of times more. Intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) fall between these, but are hard to find and study.

**What happened** – On July 24, 2025, NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope and Chandra X-ray Observatory revealed a new candidate for an intermediate-mass black hole named NGC 6099 HLX-1. This black hole was detected by its strong X-ray emissions coming from a small cluster of stars inside a giant elliptical galaxy. It appears to be consuming material from a nearby star.

**Impact** – Finding NGC 6099 HLX-1 adds to the very small number of known intermediate-mass black holes. These objects help scientists understand how black holes grow and how galaxies evolve. Studying IMBHs like this one could explain the missing link between small and supermassive black holes.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue to monitor NGC 6099 HLX-1 with telescopes to learn more about its size, behavior, and surroundings. This could lead to more discoveries of similar black holes and deepen our knowledge of cosmic history.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The discovery of NGC 6099 HLX-1 offers a rare glimpse at an intermediate-mass black hole feeding on a star, helping bridge gaps in our understanding of black hole growth and galaxy evolution.

articles.title: Hubble Captures a Tarantula
articles.summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image captures incredible details in the dusty clouds of a star-forming factory called the Tarantula Nebula. Most of the nebulae Hubble images are in our galaxy, but this nebula is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy located about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. The […]
articles.content:
This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image shows a portion of the Tarantula Nebula. ESA/Hubble & NASA, C. Murray

This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image captures incredible details in the dusty clouds of a star-forming factory called the Tarantula Nebula. Most of the nebulae Hubble images are in our galaxy, but this nebula is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy located about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa.

The Large Magellanic Cloud is the largest of the dozens of small satellite galaxies that orbit the Milky Way. The Tarantula Nebula is the largest and brightest star-forming region, not just in the Large Magellanic Cloud, but in the entire group of nearby galaxies to which the Milky Way belongs.

The Tarantula Nebula is home to the most massive stars known, some roughly 200 times as massive as our Sun. This image is very close to a rare type of star called a Wolf–Rayet star. Wolf–Rayet stars are massive stars that have lost their outer shell of hydrogen and are extremely hot and luminous, powering dense and furious stellar winds.

This nebula is a frequent target for Hubble, whose multiwavelength capabilities are critical for capturing sculptural details in the nebula’s dusty clouds. The data used to create this image come from an observing program called Scylla, named for a multi-headed sea monster from Greek mythology. The Scylla program was designed to complement another Hubble observing program called ULLYSES (Ultraviolet Legacy Library of Young Stars as Essential Standards). ULLYSES targets massive young stars in the Small and Large Magellanic Clouds, while Scylla investigates the structures of gas and dust that surround these stars.

Explore More:

Media Contact:

Claire Andreoli (claire.andreoli@nasa.gov)

NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD

articles.title: A planet the size of Saturn could orbit the nearest sun-like star
articles.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope has detected a possible gas giant the size of Saturn in the stellar system nearest our own
articles.content:
The James Webb Space Telescope has detected a possible gas giant the size of Saturn in the stellar system nearest our own

Artistic concept of what the gas giant orbiting Alpha Centauri A could look like ESA/Webb Copyright: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, R. Hurt (Caltech/IPAC)

A giant planet the size of Saturn orbiting a sun-like star has potentially been identified in our nearest neighbouring stellar system, Alpha Centauri.

At just four light years from Earth, Alpha Centauri is our closest star system. It is made up of three stars: Alpha Centauri A, Alpha Centauri B and a red dwarf star, Proxima Centauri. Researchers have long speculated Alpha Centauri could be home to a planet about as far away from a star as the Earth is to our sun – the liquid-water-friendly “habitable zone” – but confirming if any exists around the binary stars has proved challenging. That is because “[the stars] are so bright, close, and move across the sky quickly”, said Charles Beichman at the California Institute of Technology in a statement.

Advertisement

But recent data collected by the James Webb Space Telescope’s (JWST) Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) suggests a gas giant as big as Saturn may have been found orbiting Alpha Centauri A, a sun-like star. The finding came as somewhat of a surprise. “Webb was designed and optimised to find the most distant galaxies in the universe,” said Beichman, not exoplanets. He said finding this planet required meticulous planning, involving multiple observations, analysis and computer modelling, which “paid off spectacularly”.

While previous strategies to find planets have relied on indirect measurements, JWST did something “much more ambitious” by directly capturing the light from the possible planet, says Alan Boss at Carnegie Science in Washington DC, who was not involved in the study. However, the potential planet wasn’t visible in later observations.

“We are faced with the case of a disappearing planet!” said Aniket Sanghi, also at Caltech, in a statement. The team simulated millions of potential orbits to investigate this mystery. “We found that in half of the possible orbits simulated, the planet moved too close to the star and wouldn’t have been visible to Webb in both February and April 2025”, when the later observations were made, he said.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Lost in Space-Time Untangle mind-bending physics, maths and the weirdness of reality with our monthly, special-guest-written newsletter. Sign up to newsletter

As a gas giant, it could not support life as we know it. However, if confirmed, the finding could have major implications for our understanding of how planets form around stars. “Its very existence in a system of two closely separated stars would challenge our understanding of how planets form, survive, and evolve in chaotic environments,” said Sanghi. “It’s also the most similar in temperature and age to the giant planets in our solar system, and nearest to our home, Earth.”

The finding was announced in a pair of papers that have been accepted for publication in The Astrophysical Journal Letters.

Journal reference arXiv DOI: arXiv:2508.03812

articles.personality_title: James Webb Telescope spots possible Saturn-sized planet near Alpha Centauri
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Alpha Centauri is the closest star system to Earth, about four light years away. It contains three stars: Alpha Centauri A and B, which are similar to our sun, and a smaller red dwarf called Proxima Centauri. Scientists have long wondered if planets orbit these stars, especially in zones that might support liquid water.

**What happened** – Using the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) on the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), researchers detected the possible presence of a gas giant planet roughly the size of Saturn orbiting Alpha Centauri A. This discovery involved careful observations and computer modeling. Unlike previous planet searches that relied on indirect methods, JWST was able to capture direct light from the planet, marking a new approach in exoplanet detection.

**Impact** – This finding is significant because it suggests planets can be detected directly around very bright, nearby stars, which has been difficult until now. The discovery near Alpha Centauri A, our nearest sun-like star, opens up new opportunities to study planets outside our solar system in detail, potentially improving our understanding of planetary systems close to home.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to continue observing Alpha Centauri to confirm whether the detected object is indeed a planet. The fact that it has not appeared in later observations means researchers need more data to understand its nature. Future observations with JWST or other instruments will help clarify this and may lead to more discoveries around nearby stars.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The James Webb Space Telescope may have found a Saturn-sized planet orbiting our closest sun-like star, marking a new milestone in directly detecting nearby exoplanets.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le télescope James Webb détecte une planète possible de la taille de Saturne près d'Alpha Centauri
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Alpha Centauri est le système stellaire le plus proche de la Terre, à environ quatre années-lumière. Il comprend trois étoiles : Alpha Centauri A et B, semblables à notre Soleil, et une naine rouge appelée Proxima Centauri. Les scientifiques se demandent depuis longtemps si des planètes orbitent autour de ces étoiles, notamment dans des zones pouvant abriter de l'eau liquide.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Grâce à l'instrument à moyen infrarouge (MIRI) du télescope spatial James Webb (JWST), des chercheurs ont détecté la présence possible d'une planète géante gazeuse de la taille de Saturne en orbite autour d'Alpha Centauri A. Cette découverte a nécessité des observations minutieuses et des modélisations informatiques. Contrairement aux méthodes indirectes précédentes, JWST a pu capter directement la lumière de la planète, une nouvelle avancée dans la détection des exoplanètes.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle montre qu'il est possible de détecter directement des planètes autour d'étoiles très lumineuses et proches, ce qui était jusqu'ici difficile. Trouver une planète près d'Alpha Centauri A, notre étoile proche similaire au Soleil, ouvre la voie à l'étude détaillée de systèmes planétaires voisins, améliorant ainsi notre compréhension des systèmes planétaires.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont poursuivre leurs observations d'Alpha Centauri pour confirmer si l'objet détecté est bien une planète. Le fait qu'elle n'apparaisse pas lors d'observations ultérieures signifie que des données supplémentaires sont nécessaires pour mieux comprendre sa nature. De futures observations avec JWST ou d'autres instruments aideront à clarifier la situation et pourraient mener à d'autres découvertes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le télescope James Webb pourrait avoir découvert une planète de la taille de Saturne en orbite autour de notre étoile proche semblable au Soleil, marquant une avancée dans la détection directe d'exoplanètes proches.
articles.personality_title_es: El telescopio James Webb detecta posible planeta del tamaño de Saturno cerca de Alfa Centauri
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Alfa Centauri es el sistema estelar más cercano a la Tierra, a unos cuatro años luz. Está formado por tres estrellas: Alfa Centauri A y B, similares a nuestro Sol, y una enana roja llamada Próxima Centauri. Los científicos han sospechado durante mucho tiempo que podrían existir planetas orbitando estas estrellas, especialmente en zonas donde podría haber agua líquida.

**Qué pasó** – Utilizando el instrumento de infrarrojo medio (MIRI) del telescopio espacial James Webb (JWST), los investigadores detectaron un posible planeta gigante gaseoso del tamaño de Saturno orbitando Alfa Centauri A. Este hallazgo requirió observaciones cuidadosas y modelado por computadora. A diferencia de métodos previos que eran indirectos, JWST capturó directamente la luz del planeta, demostrando un nuevo método para detectar exoplanetas.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque muestra que es posible detectar directamente planetas alrededor de estrellas brillantes y cercanas, algo que ha sido difícil hasta ahora. Encontrar un planeta cerca de Alfa Centauri A, nuestra estrella parecida al Sol más cercana, abre nuevas oportunidades para estudiar sistemas planetarios fuera del nuestro con más detalle.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos continuarán observando Alfa Centauri para confirmar si el objeto detectado es realmente un planeta. El hecho de que no haya aparecido en observaciones posteriores indica que se necesitan más datos para entender su naturaleza. Futuras observaciones con JWST u otros instrumentos ayudarán a aclarar esto y podrían conducir a nuevos descubrimientos.

**Resumen en una frase** – El telescopio James Webb podría haber encontrado un planeta del tamaño de Saturno orbitando nuestra estrella más cercana parecida al Sol, marcando un avance en la detección directa de exoplanetas cercanos.
